description: Brownish but colour varies, striped and mottled forms with parts of the body varying from buff through orange to purple. Sharply incurved pronotal side-keels. Underside of body is distinctively hairy in both sexes.The species is winged, flies well and has been known to swarm. Wings reach beyond the hind-knees.
sounds: Short, brisk chirp repeated at short intervals
whenToSee: Long season with nymphs hatching from late March. Adults appear from June and may survive until early December.

description: Green-coloured but often with brown wings and sometimes entirely brown coloured. Pronotal side-keels only very slightly incurved. Some adult females are a vivid pinkish purple.Males are long-winged, while females are usually short-winged, but a fully winged form occurs (f. explicatus).
sounds: Buzzing with a rapid irregular pulse, repeated at varying intervals; similar to Heath Grasshopper but longer and quieter, lasting 3-5 seconds.
whenToSee: Long season with nymphs hatching in April. Adults appear by June and remain abundant through to September, some may survive into November.

description: Upper surfaces are brown often with black markings.  Pronotum (shield-like appendage behind the head) has a very thin pale yellow outline.  Very short wings.Underside is a striking yellow colour.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on a range of vegetation and small insects.
sounds: Brief, penetrating chip, performed throughout the day and into the night.
whenToSee: Nymphs appear at the end of April. Adults appear in late June to early July and survive until winter.
similarSpecies: Jamaican Field Cricket, Tropical House Cricket

description: Usually dark brown and yellow but sometimes tinged green or rarely completely green. Broad cream-coloured margin all the way around the sides of the pronotum, and three pale yellow spots on the sides of the thorax.Usually short-winged (brachypterous) and flightless, but a fully winged form able to fly (f. diluta) is not uncommon in hot summers
whatItEats: Omnivorous, but feeding mostly on grass and other vegetation.
sounds: Penetrating and continuous high pitched buzzing like the crackle of overhead electricity cables
whenToSee: Nymphs emerge in late May and June. Adults present from late July until autumn.

description: A small, green bush cricket with a brown stripe on the back and tiny dark speckles covering the whole body. The ovipositor is broad and upturned.Both sexes have very short, reduced wings.
whatItEats: Herbivorous, feeding on a range of shrubs and other vegetation.
sounds: The song is an almost inaudible chirp repeated at intervals, best picked up with a bat detector.
whenToSee: Adults present from late July or early August until November.

description: Green or green and brown. There is never any red or orange on the abdomen. Females are always green dorsally though green, brown or purple elsewhere. Gently incurved side-keels on the pronotum. Palps may be pale but never chalk white.Winged and flies well. In females, wings do not usually exceed the end of the body; in males they do.
sounds: Rapid, prolonged, sibilant clicking which starts quietly and rapidly increases in volume and is sustained for 10 to 20 seconds or longer
whenToSee: The first of the grasshoppers to appear in numbers, nymphs can be found from late April or May. Adults appear from July and survive into November.

description: Slender green cricket with brown wings and brown stripe along the back.Fully winged, with wings extending beyond the tip of the abdomen. An extra-long-winged form exists with much longer wings – reaching the end of the ovipositor or beyond in females.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on grasses as well as small insects.
sounds: A prolonged rapid chuffing noise inaudible to many. Louder than the song of the Short-winged Conehead, and usually NOT alternating with a second, ticking noise.
whenToSee: Nymphs emerge in late May and June. Adults present from August until early winter.

description: Similar in appearance to the Meadow Grasshopper; straw brown or light green-coloured and less brightly coloured than the Meadow Grasshopper. The side keels of the pronotum are almost parallel.Functional wings that rarely reach the end of the abdomen. The species flies readily in hot weather.
sounds: Gentle burr repeated in cycles 2-6 times. Courtship stridulation sounds like a clock being wound.
whenToSee: Mid season species with nymphs hatching in May. Adults appear from early to mid July and remain abundant through to October.

description: Small, pale green with a yellowish stripe along the back. The female has a long, slightly upturned ovipositor, the male has relatively long curved cerci (appendages at the tip of the abdomen as found in earwigs)
sounds: Does not stridulate but drums one hind leg on a leaf, in short fast bursts
whenToSee: Adults present from late July until autumn.
similarSpecies: Common Green Grasshopper, Stripe-winged Grasshopper, Heath Grasshopper

description: Small grasshopper-like insect with wide ‘shoulders’ and a narrow tapering abdomen hidden beneath an extended pronotum. Wings exceed the tip of the pronotum. The distance between the eyes is greater than in the very similar Cepero’s Groundhopper (greater than 1.5 times the width of an eye).Fully winged, capable of flight and adults can swim.
whatItEats: Herbivorous, feeding on algae, mosses and lichens.
sounds: None
whenToSee: Late instar nymphs and immature adults overwinter and mature in spring. Nymphs appear from May to July; adults appear by August.
similarSpecies: Lesser Marsh Grasshopper, Large Marsh Grasshopper

description: Small grasshopper-like insect with wide ‘shoulders’ and a narrow tapering abdomen hidden beneath an extended pronotum. More robust looking than Cepero’s and Slender Groundhopper, with a very prominent keel on the pronotum and shorter wings. There is a rare long-winged form (f. macroptera), found mainly in the Cairngorm National Park, which has a pronotum and wings similar in length to the other two species of groundhopper. The best way to distinguish it is the very prominent keel on the pronotum
sounds: None
whenToSee: Late instar nymphs and immature adults overwinter and mature in spring. Nymphs appear from May to July. Adults may be found at any time of the year.

description: Small, green bush cricket with a brown stripe along the back and brown wings. Unlike the Long-winged Conehead, this species usually has short wings that do not reach the end of the body.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, but feeds mainly on seed heads, buds and flowers of grasses, rushes and sedges.
sounds: TWO alternating sounds are characteristic: a chuffing noise similar to Long-winged Conehead but even quieter, and a rapid ticking noise, described as sounding like a fishing reel, or the old knife grinders wheel.
whenToSee: Nymphs emerge in May and June. Adults present from July and August until mid-October.

description: A small variable grasshopper (12 described colour forms). Clubbed antennae of males and thickened antennal tips of females are distinctive, both lack white tips. The side keels of the pronotum are deeply indented.Winged; strong flight over short distances.
sounds: A sequence of short buzzing sounds lasting 10-15 seconds (begins softly, reaches a climax and then stops abruptly)
whenToSee: Nymphs hatch from end of April to June. Adults appear by mid June through to October.

description: Very large, leaf green cricket with a brown stripe along the back. The female has a long, slightly down-curved ovipositor.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, eating a variety of plants and insects.
sounds: Loud and penetrating song that can be heard over a long distance. It is performed from the late afternoon into the night, often from bushes or trees.
whenToSee: Nymphs emerge in May and June. Adults present from late July until early winter.
similarSpecies: Great Green Bush Cricket, Sickle-bearing Bush-cricket

description: Brightly coloured, usually green and brown with red on the abdomen. Gently incurved pronotal keels. Winged with a white line and elongated spot (stigma) on the forewing.
sounds: Short, pulsating, metallic rasp – characteristic ‘wheezing’ hiss.
whenToSee: Nymphs appear in May, adults from mid-July onwards surviving until October.

description: Small, pale green cricket with a yellowish stripe along the back. The female has a long, slightly upturned ovipositor, the male has long curved cerci (appendages at the tip of the abdomen as found in earwigs) . Unlike the Oak Bush Cricket, this species only has very short wings (although beware of Oak Bush Cricket nymphs, which also have short wings).
sounds: Does not stridulate but drums one hind leg on a leaf, in short fast bursts.
whenToSee: Late - adults present from the middle of August until autumn.

description: Green or brown but with bright green underside. The pronotum (shield-like appendage behind the head) has a cream-coloured band only along the hind edge of the sides (unlike Roesel’s Bush Cricket, where the band goes all the way round the pronotum).
whatItEats: Mainly vegetarian, feeding on buds, seeds and flowers.
sounds: Soft but shrill buzz like rapidly ticking watch
whenToSee: Nymphs hatch in May and June. Adults from July until late autumn.

description: Variable but usually greyish brown. Females have a long, upturned ovipositor.Both sexes fully winged unlike similar Dark Bush-cricket which has very short wings.
sounds: Soft, rapidly repeated, high pitched chirp
whenToSee: Nymphs hatch in May. Adults appear in July to autumn.

description: Dark greyish brown; underside of the posterior of the abdomen in mature adults is red or orange. The tips of the palps (mouthparts) are almost white. Pronotal keels incurved. Females exhibit two colour forms: all brown or with green forewings and upperside of the head and pronotum.Fully winged.
sounds: Sibilant clicking, starting quietly and increasing in volume before ending abruptly. Each song lasts 5-10 seconds.
whenToSee: Nymphs appear from April or May. Adults appear in June and rarely survive beyond mid-October.

description: A small, dark brown cricket with a paler pronotumFlightless with reduced forewings
sounds: Low purring song that is difficult to hear from a solitary male but can be heard from a chorus of males.
whenToSee: Adults present from June to the end of October.

description: Small grasshopper-like insect with wide ‘shoulders’ and a narrow tapering abdomen hidden beneath an extended pronotum. Wings exceed the tip of the pronotum. The distance between the eyes is smaller than in the very similar Slender Groundhopper (no more than 1.5 times the width of an eye).
sounds: None
whenToSee: Late instar nymphs and immature adults overwinter and mature in spring. Nymphs appear from May to July; adults appear by August.

description: Broad bodied, brown grasshopper with clubbed, pale or white-tipped antennae. Mature males have orange tip to abdomen. Incurved pronotal side-keels. Some females are reddish-purple.Fully winged.
sounds: Soft but urgent buzzing which fluctuates slightly, dying away at the end.
whenToSee: Nymphs hatch in late May. Adults appear by late July and can survive into December.

description: Greyish brown cricket with two dark bars across the head, and cerci (appendages at the tip of the abdomen as found in earwigs) no longer than the ovipositor.Fully winged.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on a wide range of animal and vegetable matter.
sounds: Regular, shrill chirp.
whenToSee: Lives in artificial conditions and lacks seasonality or diapause (seasonal interruptions to development).

description: Greyish brown with body and legs covered in minute scales.Wingless
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on decaying plant and animal matter.
sounds: None, as the species has no wings.
whenToSee: Nymphs have been recorded in April, adults from August to October.

description: Largest native grasshopper, yellowish green to olive brown in colour with bright red undersides of the hind leg thighs. A plum coloured form is sometimes observed in females. Females are larger than males.Fully winged and flies well.
sounds: Characteristic popping stridulation made by kicking the wings with the hind legs. 1-3 clicks per second, in verses lasting 5-10 seconds.
whenToSee: Nymphs emerge in late spring. Adults appear from late July and survive until early November.

description: Dark, greyish brown with little variation. The pronotum (shield-like appendage behind the head) has incurved side-keels and dark wedge-shaped markings, looking like an hourglass from above. In mature adults the abdomen develops an orange or orange-red tinge.
sounds: Buzzing with a rapid irregular pulse, repeated at varying intervals; similar to the Meadow Grasshopper but slower and louder, lasting 5-6 seconds.
whenToSee: Short season with nymphs hatching in May. Adults appear by late June and July but only survive until October.
similarSpecies: Southern Oak Bush-cricket, Short-winged Conehead, Oak Bush-cricket, Great Green Bush-cricket

description: Shiny black cricket with a large head. The forewings have a yellow base, the thighs are red on the underside.Forewings extend beyond the middle of the abdomen, hindwings are only vestigial.
sounds: Males have a loud song consisting of short chirps repeated several times a second, which is performed in front of their burrows and can be heard up to 100m.
whenToSee: Late instar nymphs and adults overwinter in distinctive burrows with horizontal entrances. Adults are present from April onwards, they mate and lay eggs from May to July and die by August.

description: Large cricket, light chestnut coloured and covered with velvet-like hairs; large, very strong forelegs that are modified for digging.Forewings are short but both sexes can fly and do so at night.
whatItEats: Vegetable material, insect larvae and earthworms.
sounds: Male stridulation is a loud continuous purring.
whenToSee: Lives underground and only sings for a few days around May.

description: A large cricket, typically found as the green form in England, which is speckled with black wing markings.  It has big, dark eyes and a muscular appearance with powerful hind legs. The ovipositor is curved slightly upwards – unlike in the similar looking Great Green Bush Cricket.
whatItEats: Omnivorous: eats herbs but also insects including other grasshoppers.
sounds: Fairly loud and distinctive, rapidly repeated clicks that often start slow and get faster
whenToSee: Adults present from July until autumn.

description: Large brownish grasshopper with dark patches on the hind wings and multiple vertical bars down the eyes. Peg between the forelegs and a prominent keel in the middle of the pronotum that is broken by three deep transverse furrows.Fully winged with wings extending beyond the end of the abdomen in both sexes.
sounds: None
whenToSee: Adults have been found in Britain from late summer through to November.
similarSpecies: Southern Oak Bush-cricket, Speckled Bush-cricket, Great Green Bush-cricket

description: Both sexes have forewings extending beyond the tip of the abdomen. Female’s wings are almost black. Both these characteristics distinguish the species from the Field Cricket.
sounds: Series of loud, ringing chirps that come at a rate of several a second and can be heard from quite a long distance.
whenToSee: Can occur all year round.
similarSpecies: Roesel’s Bush Cricket, Grey Bush-cricket, Dark Bush-cricket

description: Yellow-green with very long wings. Forewings markedly shorter than hindwings. The ovipositor is short, broad, and sharply upturned.Both sexes have very long wings. Forewings reach the hind knees, hindwings extend much further back still. The species flies well.
sounds: The song is an indistinct tzzp… tzzp…
whenToSee: Adults present from August onwards.
similarSpecies: Bog Bush-cricket, Grey Bush-cricket, Dark Bush-cricket

description: The “gregarious” form that is most likely to be found in Britain is a large yellow-brown grasshopper with multiple vertical bars down the eyes. Peg between the forelegs, but no central keel on the pronotum. Nymphs appear quite different from the adults; they are bright yellow with contrasting black markings. Adults of the solitary form are greenish with a humped thorax.In the gregarious form, both sexes have long wings and fly well.
sounds: Short burst of rapid ticking.
whenToSee: Adults appear late summer to early autumn, though escapes may occur all year round.
similarSpecies: Field Grasshopper, Rufous Grasshopper, Mottled Grasshopper

description: The “gregarious” form that is most likely to be found in Britain is a large greyish-brown to rufous grasshopper with a single horizontal bar across the eyes.  In the gregarious form, both sexes have long wings and fly well. There is no peg between the forelegs, and no prominent central keel on the pronotum. Nymphs are orange-brown. Adults of the solitary form are greyish-green with a humped thorax.
sounds: Short burst of rapid ticking.
whenToSee: True vagrants are most likely to arrive on warm south-easterly winds in late summer or early autumn. Escapes may occur all year round.

description: Smallest grasshopper; usually green with brownish wings and sometimes develops orange-red colouration on the tip of the abdomen. Males have thickened, but not clubbed, antennae.Wings just short of reaching the tip of the abdomen.
sounds: Unobtrusive series of chirps in bursts of 1-4 seconds duration.
whenToSee: Eggs hatch in May and adults appear in early July to mid-October.

description: A large, cryptically coloured grasshopper with darker bands across the forewings and a marked keel on the pronotum. Distinctive in flight when bright blue basal patches with dark borders on the hind wings are shown.
sounds: Only heard during courtship; soft, short buzzing.
whenToSee: Adults appear in late July through to October and early November.

description: Slender grasshopper which is brownish or straw coloured, the side keels on the pronotum are almost parallelWinged and flying readily. Wings do not reach the end of the abdomen.
sounds: A series of brief zzip sounds at the rate of one per second for up to 30 seconds
whenToSee: Nymphs hatch in May. Adults are present from early July to October.
similarSpecies: Common Green Grasshopper, Field Grasshopper, Stripe-winged Grasshopper

description: A slender, pale brown, almost translucent cricket. The head is narrowever than the body.
sounds: Pleasant melodious purr
whenToSee: Adults present from August onwards.
similarSpecies: Field Grasshopper, Stripe-winged Grasshopper, Woodland Grasshopper

description: Fully winged but rarely observed in flight.  Active at night. The wings are ear-shaped (the name earwig was originally ear-wing) and like in all earwig species they are folded up in an extremely complicated way to fit under the tiny wing cases. Commonest species of earwig in Europe. The 'forceps' are curved in the male and straight in the female.
whatItEats: Detritus- and plant-feeder - mainly decaying plant material, but sometimes flowers.
whenToSee: Four nymphal instars (continental populations have five).  Adults can be observed throughout the year but are most noticeable in autumn (commonly shaken from dahlias and chrysanthemums in gardens). Females are capable of two generations. The female earwig

description: Hindwings absent or greatly reduced. Pale, small version of the Common Earwig but hindwings are absent or greatly reduced. The cerci are flattened and straight up to approximately half their total length.
whenToSee: Adults usually seen from July to October.

description: Fully developed wings, which are folded away when not in use. This earwig is much more likely to take flight than the Common Earwig and regularly visits outside lights at night. Likened superficially to a rove (staphylinid) beetle although presence of forceps easily identify it as an earwig.  Dull, yellowish brown with a pubescent body and dark head.  Similar to the Common Earwig but smaller and less shiny.  Smallest earwig in Europe.
whatItEats: Detritus feeder - decaying plant material in warm places.
whenToSee: Life cycle of about three months.  Breeding and development occur all year and all stages can be found together where there is moist, consistent, natural heating. Like Common Earwigs, they show considerable maternal care of their eggs and young and even f

description: Hind wings are only tiny lobes and it is therefore flightless. Reddish brown with yellow legs.  Slightly smaller than the Common Earwig, and it is light brown all over. In contrast to the Common Earwig, the species also lacks a tooth on the inside of the pincers in both sexes.
whenToSee: Active all year around except during periods of frost.  Adults present from August to September but they are nocturnal.
similarSpecies: Grey Bush-cricket, Bog Bush-cricket, Roesel's Bush-cricket

description: Males have long tapering forewings and fly well.  Females have short truncated forewings and vestigial hindwings and are flightless. Dark brown with speckled patterning on the pronotum in both sexes and on females also on the dorsal surface of the abdomen.
whenToSee: Eggs hatch in late April or May and the nymphs (distinctive white patterns on the thorax) pass through five instars.  Adults are present from July until early October.
similarSpecies: Dark Bush-cricket, Roesel's Bush-cricket, Bog Bush-cricket

description: Males are fully winged.  Females have vestigial wings and are flightless. Light, even greyish, brown. Often very pale, females are darker and have a shorter, broader shape.
whenToSee: Two year life cycle with five nymphal instars.  Adults present from end of May to the end of September.  Nymphs overwinter in the fourth instar where they can be found in grass tussocks and deep leaf litter from October to March.

description: Both sexes are fully winged and capable of flight. Distinctive golden brown colour. Pale with black eyes.
whenToSee: Two year life cycle with six nymphal instars.  Adults are present from late June until October and even November.  Nymphs overwinter in the fourth instar resuming development in April.

description: Both sexes fully winged. Large size. Has yellow markings on the pronotum.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on refuse and anything edible that is not too dry and hard.
whenToSee: Indoors adults may be seen all year round.

description: Females have very short vestigial wings, males have longer wings, but both sexes are flightless. Large species of cockroach, dark brown to black in colour with a glossy body.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on refuse and anything edible that is not too dry and hard.
whenToSee: Indoors adults may be seen all year round.
similarSpecies: Common Green Grasshopper, Mottled Grasshopper, Field Grasshopper

description: Both sexes are fully winged and can fly, though they rarely do so. Yellowish brown and has variable stripes on the pronotum.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on refuse and anything edible that is not too dry and hard.
whenToSee: Indoors adults may be seen all year round.
similarSpecies: Meadow Grasshopper, but this is not as big and does not have such distinctive hind leg markings

description: Both sexes are fully winged and fly well in warm conditions. Large size.  When threatened, it can produce a foul-smelling secretion from glands in its abdomen.
whatItEats: Omnivorous, feeding on refuse and anything edible that is not too dry and hard.
whenToSee: Indoors adults may be seen all year round.

description: Both sexes are fully winged and fly well in warm weather. Usually green, sometimes brown.
whatItEats: Carnivorous, feeding on other insects including grasshoppers and bush crickets.
whenToSee: In the native range, adults appear from July to November.

description: Green or brown. The Unarmed Stick-insect and the Smooth Stick-insect appear similar at first glance. They can distinguished because the Smooth Stick-insect has a near continuous black line along its thorax, has pointed cerci, and has no opercular spine.
whenToSee: Adult insects can be seen from April through to December.

description: Either green or brown. With numerous black spines over its body, the Prickly Stick-insect is unmistakable.
whenToSee: Adult insects can be seen from April through to December.
similarSpecies: Wartbiter, Sickle-bearing Bush-cricket, Long-winged Conehead, Oak Bush-cricket, Speckled Bush-cricket
